												Have you ever tried out a roguelike and wanted to like it, but just couldn't get into its punishing nature?I have, and no matter how many times I tried to get into the genre, for the most part I couldn't find one that was for me.And then Rogue Legacy came around, with its Castlevania-inspired gameplay, randomized character-trait system that always added a unique flair to the gameplay, and the constant sense of accomplishment with the numerous upgrades available at your keep, and I couldn't stop playing the game.Every time I'd get to the point of "just one more run," I'd find myself getting even more gold than I did the previous run, and then I'd want to go spend it on something in the keep, and then I'd try again, and before I knew it I had played another hour.Addictive doesn't even begin to describe it.Buy this game, hook up your favorite gamepad (or buy one because this game plays SOOO good with one), and then watch as time flies as you try to uncover more and more of the castle and/or find tons of gold.

content:
er 29, 2013
												While the rogue-like (permadeath) system coupled with the randomizing castle can make you feel like you aren't making any progress initially, the game surprises with the gradual gains of building out your manor to unlock new classes and bonuses.The inclusion of traits adds more depth to the experience, even when the traits do nothing from a gameplay standpoint (e.g. baldness or being gay). It's kind of fulfilling in its own right to power through the castle with a lesbian dwarf ninja.The game has a good sense of humor, and there are nodding references here and there to other media (e.g. Skyrim, Naruto), and there is enough of a rhythm once you've upgraded things a bit to offset the frustration of starting from scratch every time you die (and you will die many, many times). Note that you do have the option to "freeze" the castle layout at a -40% gold intake penalty once you unlock the Architect.The concept is great, and the execution is clever and full of charm. I hope to see more games from this team.Notes:-Spellsword+Vampirism is a mighty combination.-The game can frustrate you by offering puzzles that are only possible if you re-equip and lock the castle layout.-Some traits that sound negative can be surprisingly useful (e.g. P.A.D., Dwarfism, O.C.D.).-It's nice to play as a gay hero (without any stereotypical humor), especially after reading the developer's comments on why they included it.

10, 2014
												Rogue Legacy is a rougelike game made by Celler Door Games, who also made Don't **** your pants and Tribal Tallies. So you're thinking this won't be a great game based of their previous games. It isn't. Rogue Legacy brings in some very unique gameplay that makes it fun and enjoyable. You play as a hero with a class as they enter the castle looting and killing baddies until they die. They will be remembered by how well you played in the castle and each time you die, your descendants will continue where you left off, or at least do better than you did. And sometimes they can have good or bad traits depending on what the RNG gives you. But each time you enter the castle. You have to pay a fee with Cheron before you can enter and each time you enter, the castle will randomize itself, so you always expect different results each time (unless you use the architect to keep the castle the way it is).There are RPG elements added in the game to beef off your heroes. Such as increasing stats and gaining new classes and abilities in the manor. You can also gain runes and blueprints for equipment in the castle for your son/daughter to wield the next time they enter, some giving them unique abilities when equip. There's also a training dummy to see how strong your attacks are. Sometimes there will be fairy chest challenges that will be needed to be done before you can obtain the runes and later stats upgrade once you obtained all the runes. Some are nearly impossible to do and others are really simple if you have the right tools or you know what you are doing. There are minibosses you can fight too for bluepritns and stats upgrade too that appear rarely. So it's worth it to fight them if you have enough health to withstand their attacks.The story is simple. The tutorials give you a hint on what happened before you entered the castle with your heroes and later near the end explains what happens. It may not be heavily story based, but the story seems to work well with the game.There are also minigames you can play too, such as carnival games and pick the right chest to gain profits or lose it all. They are hard, but with the right tools and strageties, you can earn some neat stuff.There are negative stuff to be had too. One, this game is really frustrating. Expect to die alot from careless mistakes or not being lucky enough. It even sucks when the characters you choose will have really bad traits and can't trade them in (until you get a upgrade that allows you to reroll your children). And second, it's a grindfest. If you want to beat bosses and enemies and last longer in the castle, get alot of money for upgrades. Usually Cheron takes all your money, but upgrading the haggle skill allows you to keep some money for later purchases, which is good. All in all, this is a wonderful game. It has neat graphics, cool soundtracks, and it's addicting to play. But the frustrating levels and the hardcore grinding makes it hard to really love this game when it's not being evil to you.Rating 8/10

ber 16, 2013
												While the game starts slow (you're going to die very often and very quickly), the nature of the gameplay works to its own advantage--you can play for so long, get frustrated at dying so quickly, stop for a bit, and then come back to it later. The game itself is incredibly fun and charming, with so many little extras that make every new character feel unique and worth playing (even if sometimes your heir options suck). It definitely keeps you coming back for more, and well worth the price. Good for gamers who can't focus for very long periods of time!

8, 2014
												Rogue Legacy is as you could imagine a game about getting money, remember Binding of Isaac and how that seemed challenging? Well when you play this game you will change your mind, this game is filled with challanges, powerful mobs, heroes with annoting, hard and sometimes useful traits but most of all a lot of fun.This game has been designed for people that know how to play hack and slash games and get get through the hard territories even with Vertigo, Stereo blindess and Colour Blindness.Through out the game you gotta earn money to expand your mannor, that's the only way you will survive further through the endless corridors of the castle in order to defeat the 1st out of 4 beasts, expanding your mannor will grant you things like more health, armour, attack and armour capacity, but also you'll be able to unlock new classes, upgrades to those classes, and other utilities, but importantly, unlock the Blacksmith, that will sell armour, Enchantress who will sell runes (NOTE: all those things you first gotta find in the castle) and an arichtect who for a a 30% of your money will lock the castle, why would it be useful? Say if you found a good spot to get money or found the boss room or even just you like the castle, well then that's useful (Looted chests will stay looted when you lock the castle).About a story, well the story isn't told to your directly, but me telling you it would ruin the fun, basically the story is contained in the Prince's Journals that you will find through out the castle and it definately is worth a read.So is the game worth buying, I say yes, I myself haven't seen many people deny that, this game is a lot of fun and a challenge, I like challenges myself and although the game is sometimes frustrating of how hard it can get, however after a few seconds break I get back to the game and I've already killed two of the four bosses.Sory wise once you start reading the story you might actually not want to stop, the story gets quite intense plus it kinda ruins the ending once you do get to the ending of the journals, but its still a good read, unless you have dyslexia... then its just confusing.Anyway I rate this game 9 evil paintings out of 10, my highest rating yet but I can see the game deserves it. So go ahead, buy it since its on sale! You won't regret it!

												So addictive! Rogue Legacy is one of the best games I've bought in a while. Interesting game mechanics combined with plenty of humour and nerdy references make this game quite fun to play. It's nice that the game doesn't force you to constantly backtrack unless you want to (it's optional~), so every playthrough feels fresh. Dying a lot is one of the main features of the game, but it doesn't feel tedious at all; instead, it'll have you saying "Just one more heir, and then I'm done" over and over again until you realize that you've been playing for 4 hours longer than you meant to. It's also nice that there are so many different character options every time you die, so you can change your play style to whatever suits your current mood. 10/10

2, 2014
												Overview:GET. THIS. GAME. ♥♥♥♥ING. RIGHT. NOW.Details:Graphics 5/5 (for not diverging from its late-90s RPG-style)Gameplay 5/5 (it is extremely simple and enjoyable)Lasting Appeal 5/5 (more on that down there)Review:This game is an awesome Roguelike hybrid. It is a bubbling cauldron of 2-D action platformer, Roguelike, and tower defense. AND IT'S STILL GREAT! When you die (WHEN you die), you upgrade various slots on your Mansion with the gold you earned going through Castle Hamson to better various skills and attain new abilities. Then (the most interesting, unexpected, and well-blended feature I've ever seen in a Roguelike video game) you choose one of three heirs to go through the castle again, with the new skills/abilities/equipment/runes you got with the previous character[s].This game is a STEAL at $15. Get it now.

												An excellent Castlevania-style platformer with roguelike elements. Because gold and upgrades carry over between characters, permadeath doesn't make you feel like your run was wasted when you eventually miss a jump and fall onto a bed of spikes. Combat is fairly simple, but pleasantly fast-paced, and the assorted challenge rooms, random positive and negative perks, and various other nuances make repeated trips into the castle very entertaining. I do wish there was a bit more enemy variety (there's a fair number of palette swaps), and some of the rooms show up more often than I'd like, but overall Rogue Legacy is definitely worth a look for platformer fans and roguelike fans alike.

4, 2013
												An enjoyable and utterly addicitive Metroidvania/rogue-"lite". The sprite work in regards to both the enemies and the castle's various backgrounds is sharp, colorful, and all-around fantastic. Between the procedurally-generated castle layouts and the unique geneological trait system, the game is able to stay fresh from one run to the next and maintain a nice sense of randomness. The progression/skill tree is surprisingly deep and will require a lot of playtime to fill out. Intimidating bosses and rooms packed to the brim with enemies help create a healthy, satisfying challenge. I also like how the game gives you the freedom to explore the entire castle right off the bat, yet punishes you if you travel to specific areas out of the intended order (a la Dark Souls). Perhaps most impressive, though, is what could best be described as a "masterful" soundtrack. Every time I hear the theme for the Maya/Tower, I smile with joy. The music in this game is just so well done.On the downside, while the platforming and combat controls work well for the most part and are simple to get a hang of, the analog controls tend to be a bit over-sensitive. There have been quite a few instances where I've screwed up and felt it was more a matter of the game's controls being imprecise than it was my own fault. Also, while still fun more than 20+ hours into playing, the experience does tend to feel a little grind-y once you get far into New Game+ territory.Problems aside, Rogue Legacy manages to do so many things well and so few things wrong. It does a terrific job of scratching that old-school Metroid/Castlevania itch and provides a sense of accomplishment with each run. A game that's easy to pick up and play in short 30 minute bursts, or spend hours on end with. Highly recommended.

ber 17, 2014
												At first, I only bought this game because i liked the art style, but now, after beating the main story, I absolutely love this game.To start, the whole concept of "no two castles are the same" is done very well, with defferent rooms challenging different classes, plus there being secrets for characters with specific traits. The enimies are varied and intersting, esepcially the mini-bosses, even though at the beginning, you won't last very long. If you continue playing though, your skills will increase, as well as your armour, runes and stats. The 4 main bosses of each area are fun and are diffuclt, being extremley hard to beat them on your first time ( except the 4th boss, he is too weak to be the 4th area boss.) The controls are very good, with all the key assingments feeling natural. The finally thing is that the music in Rogue Legacy is some of the finest indie music I've heard. Overall, If you are a fan of Metroid, or the Metroid-Vanias, or are looking for a great indie game, this is the game for you. Also, on a side note, my longest living character was a midget, bald, assaisan.

												I really, really enjoyed this game, and if the following words mean anything to you, I think you will as well:Arcade platformer metroidvania roguelike.Still with me?It took me 102 deaths and 16.5 hours to beat this thing. Unlike other roguelikes, it's very probable that you will beat this game after investing enough time into it, thanks to a life-to-life upgrade progression system that other roguelikes don't possess. As Rogue Legacy is super fun to play, that won't be hard to consider doing.Like most roguelikes the game's dungeon is different every time you play, but you can sacrifice a bug chunk of your money of your money (used for upgrades between lives) to keep the dungeon the same, keeping access to all the warp points you've uncovered, etc. This feature is theoretically good for fighting the game's bosses until you win, as they are very difficult and will take multiple tries to beat. But as bosses always drop a ton of cash, I never bothered with that. In fact, I effectively never used the feature -- not because I'm super hardcore, but it's just in my best interests. The more money I get, the faster I upgrade, the faster I will eventually beat the boss in its due time.Even if you have played other roguelikes and didn't enjoy them, I recommend you download the demo to Rogue Legacy and give it a shot. As death is your chance to spend your money and upgrade your lineage; like it's the only way to Level Up and if you're an RPG fan, you know Leveling Up is fun.  This is a rare example of a game that actually makes it fun to fail.  If you like action platforming, the game is an incredible value with fun mechanics and charming aesthetics.

												Rogue Legacy is apply named it's very 'Rogue' like. You're not expected to win on your first playthrough, you're just supposed to do a little bit better, each time spending your hard earned gold on upgrades, runes & abilities. The game mechanics are in a way close to Binding of Isaac & Dark Souls, the death isn't the end but instead a teaching tool. After each time you die, you get a little farther because it let's you get a feel of the enemies, the traps, the world and how they work. After enough time you'll be able to see traps coming but if you perish from them, well that's on you. The game teaches you on how each enemy works and it does it very well.Even though I've only spent two hours playing it, I've been focusing on all the little details on how this game is very fun, very addicting and each time a very rewarding experience. Thoroughly enjoy this game and highly reccomend.

												Rogue Legacy. Damn, I love this game. It's so fun. Anyways, Rogue Legacy is a rogue-lite game that requires you to kill 4  bosses in order to open a golden throne room, that I have yet to know what's inside. The game is quite difficult, let me just say that. When you die, your children will succeed you. You pick one child and you use them you hopefull finish the game. Then when you die after, you always have 3 children to choose from. When you die, you don't have to completely restart. You keep all your equipment, and all the points you spent on the manor (your perks such as more health, more mana, attack power up, etc.) So you level up with each point in the manor. Now, the gameplay. You basically can move and jump and slash and cast spells to kill enemies. Pretty simple. You can also have a smithy who has the equipment *note: you must find blueprints for your smithy to be able to make it, then you buy it.* The enchantress can enchant your equipment with runes to give extra bonuses and power ups. *note: you must also find the runes yourself.* There's a lot more to the game, but that's all I can explain now. Verdict: 9/10. BUY THE GAME NOW! FULL PRICE! NOW! THE SECOND YOU READ THIS!

												My legacy has gone rogue. My 7-year-old has been playing it and he likes the Knight class so much he doesn't want to upgrade it to the Paladin... which means that he cannot unlock any upgrades and his potentially awe-inspiring castle remains a small fort. Each to their own, I suppose.Anyway, I enjoyed this game - great for a quick blast, plenty to explore and I felt great about finding the hidden class (at the top of the flagpole). It seems very much designed for an XBox controller, though, so playing on mouse and keyboard was difficult (I had to work out and write down the mappings from XBox controls to keyboard controls, plus the down-attack move to activate platforms is far too difficult on the default settings).It would be nice to carry over money from previous generations to allow the more casual player to build up a fortune... as it was, I found it increasingly difficult to be able to spend my money on anything useful (but did find that investing in the 'vampire' items and runes helped my character survive for longer to get the money). Also, some guidance on the order to attempt the other levels would be useful too (unless I missed something in the notes). Still, I enjoyed the various classes and weird hero traits, and the game overall.

y 9, 2014
												I was bored. I was looking for something fun and light to take my mind away from all the more serious games I'd been playing. I found it.Well, truth be told, I wasn't actually expecting to enjoy Rogue Legacy all that much, I really only picked it up because a friend had recommended it, and fully expected to get bored quickly. That's basically the opposite of what happened.The graphics are cute, and who doesn't like to do the occasional dungeon-crawl with adorable graphics? I was hooked within minutes. At this point, I find myself playing it for a little while most days. I'll decide "just one more character, just one more dungeon-crawl and then I'll go to bed... A few hours and a whole bunch of deaths later, I usually do. This is probably one of the most addictive little games I've played in a long time. The idea behind it is really very simple. You play a child from each of a succession of generations of one family, you can choose which, out of three random options, and in you go. The dungeon is different each time, unless you pay the Architect to give you the same one again, and until you pay for the upgrade that lets you pay Charon a little less, the ferryman charges you all your gold to get in. That's a real pain, makes it harder to stockpile your gold. You need that gold to upgrade your stats. Eventually, you face the bosses in it, but you can choose when to go through those doors, and they stay defeated through each generation after they're beaten. The story itself is told through diary pages that you find randomly.But sometimes the simplest ideas are the best, and this game is a whole lot of fun.

y 26, 2014
												When you think of roguelikes, you normally think of randomness, high difficulty, and most importantly, permadeath. Dying in those games is very serious, you lose everything: Characters, stats, items, all gone. In that genre, death really means Game Over. But what if it didn’t have to be that way? Enter Rogue Legacy.You are a warrior tasked with exploring a magical castle and defeating monsters within, with Castlevania-like gameplay that should be familiar to everyone. The twist is that, when you die, that character is gone, and you start playing as one of their heirs, with different traits and classes. The money and treasure gathered by the deceased are passed on, and you can spend them on upgrades and equipments for the new generations.The game manages to keep a constant sense of progress with the upgrade system; dying is not the end, it’s the beginning of a new adventure where you’re likely to be better prepared. It’s not just about getting better stats and armor, either, you’ll also unlock new classes and mechanical improvements, like dashes and air jumps.Your descendants are, however, randomly generated. This goes for both class and traits, the latter of which are characteristics like "Glaucoma" or "Dwarfism" that can be very helpful, irrelevant, or highly crippling. The unreliability inherent to the heirs often forces you to adapt to something that "will do" instead of having the best for the task available, which makes victory all the more sweet.And of course, it wouldn’t be a roguelike if the journey through the castle was always the same. It changes, but not simply for each game: It changes on every single generation. This is why you don’t want to die too early: You miss the chance to get a lot of loot, and boss rooms are transferred elsewhere. On the other hand, a new character means new treasure to find, so it’s not that bad. It’s fun, both to win, and to lose.And that is Rogue Legacy: A game that avoids being frustrating, but still without making you feel you’re getting off easy. All the balance in the gameplay elements really shows that a lot of effort was put into making this game, and it paid off, because Rogue Legacy makes for a fantastic roguelike*, and probably for one of the best Castlevanias out there, too.* “Roguelite”, if you prefer.PS: Use of a controller is highly recommended.

ry 19, 2014
												Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/rogue-legacy-game-review/Ahh, Rogue Legacy. My favorite rogue-like game, although it also served as my introduction to the genre. Even after playing a lot of others from the genre now, I still look back on Rogue Legacy as my favorite out of the bunch.The game is presented in a pixel fashion, making use of some nice looking sprites for the various people and enemies you will meet along your journey. This style fits well, especially for a game of this genre. Come to think of it, I don't think I've played a rogue-like that was not in this style, and I've played several of them over the past several months. Can't really complain either, there's nothing wrong with it and I'd actually prefer this style in a rogue-like game, although I may be a bit biased there (heh).Rogue Legacy's niche is the rebirth mechanic. Upon dying as one character, you'll have the choice as to which of the three offspring of that character you'll play as next. The interesting thing about this mechanic however, is that each child has separate traits, disguised as real world disorders and conditions. These can either be in your favor or against it. ADHD, for example, works in your favor in that your character will move 30% faster than usual. My favorite defect is vertigo, which mirrors the screen vertically. Yes, everything, including menus. Vertigo is a pain to deal with as I cannot rotate my monitor upside down, forcing me to play upside-down.Aside from that gimmick, the other half of the game is the immense class and upgrade system. You'll start off with no skills, playing as the default class, the knight. Upon death, the opportunity to choose offspring with a different class is presented. The basic classes to choose from contain classes such as: mage, knave, knight, barbarian, shinobi, miner, etc. Each class can be upgraded, getting a name change in the process. The shinobi, for example, changes into the hokage, my favorite class. Each class has its own advantages and disadvantages, keep that in mind.The shinobi/hokage has the benefit of upgraded strength (175% to be exact), but at the cost of only having 60% HP, 40% MP, and not being able to take advantage of critical hits. I never really used the game's spells, so the MP cut didn't have much of an effect on me, but the HP and critical hits were quite the drawback. Even so, whenever I was given the opportunity to play as a hokage, I always took it. You can't beat 175% damage. I found it crucial to defeating some of the game's bosses. I actually defeated the forest boss (the second one I took on) without getting hit as a hokage, quite the achievement.On top of the classes, there's also a plethora of upgrades to choose from each time you die. The upgrades are laid out in a branching format, with certain upgrades unlocking others. The first one made available is Smithy, the blacksmith. Once purchased, you'll be able to purchase both armor and weapons from him. There's also an architect (who can keep the last layout of the castle if you choose to not want the game to randomly generate another castle again) and an enchantress, who sells runes, which can be equipped to provide various abilities (like the ability to jump while in air).The other upgrades consist of class upgrades (like barbarian -> barbarian king) and stat upgrades. This consists of mana, health, and equip upgrades. Equip upgrades allow you to carry more weight and is required if you ever want to wear good armor. There's plenty of other upgrades to base skills (attack up, magic damage up, armor up, etc.) and a few unique ones, like "death defy" and "haggle". Death defy, as you can probably tell, allows you to defy death (1.5% everytime the upgrade is purchased). Haggle, on the other hand, lowers Charon's toll when entering the castle.The game's map is divided into five zones: the front "safe" area at the entrance to the castle, the castle, the maya (above the castle), the dungeon (below the castle), and the forest (to the right of the castle). Each area (aside from the safe area) has its own boss that needs to be defeated if you want to unlock the golden door at the entrance of the castle. These bosses are very difficult if you're not properly equipped (I did tell you about my love for the hokage class, right?). Each time you die and want to re-enter the castle, you'll have to give up all of your funds earned during the previous run to Charon, who guards the entrance to the castle.Rogue Legacy is a fantastic game overall. The sense of progression is really profound and it just feels really, really satisfying to defeat the bosses and open that golden door. Now that it's only $15, why not give it a shot?

y 30, 2014
												After years of playing overly involved games like EVE-Online, Elder Scrolls series games and other assorted RPG's, I've decided that maybe my gaming was taking up too much of my time and decided to go with games that can get me a quick fix then I can move on with my life.Damn you Rouge Legacy, damn you.  Yes, it does fit the quick fix.   But it's like smoke crack.  Just one more time!  I promise..   I used to curse Eve Online for the sheer planning and time consumed carrying out mundane things like putting up a player owned station...  Now I'm cursing Rouge Legacy because there comparitively little planning involved, yet it still consumes too much of my time.  It's a stupid platformer.  I hate it.  But I can't stop playing it.  So I am highly recommending this game to everyone but my children because misery loves company.On a more serious note --  this is a great little "rouge-like".  The controls aren't exactly tight as some other reviews will lead you to believe - they are however twich based and Castlevania styled.  The gimmick of having heirs works suprisingly well.  My biggest gripe is not having Steam Cloud support - just lost a hard drive - and while I was mirroring a large portion of my data, my save games didn't make it.I would recommend buying this game when it is on sale.  As much as I like it, $14.99 is asking a lot for what amounts to an arcade game.

												This game is amazingly good, one of the only games that I would truly recommend to anybody, like I would reccomend Hotline Miami to just about anyone. The game's mechanics are soo smooth so that your sprints easily transitions into double jumps and maybe even flight (If you are about that life). I just love this game, the only thing bad about it is that the story is lacking, just like all of the other Rogue-likes, and that the enemies are just recolored as they level up throughout your time playing the game. The game changes a lot over the new game +'s to the point where the bloodshots from floating eyeballs don't seem so bad compared to the spam from flamelocks, and then those flamelocks seem scrawny nexy to those dang plinkies. This game has so much entertainment to offer that it is definitively one of my favorite singleplayer games of all time (Bastion is still the best).

2, 2015
												Truth be told, I am not a huge fan of Roguelike games on a whole. Despite their mechanical purity and focus on strong gameplay, they often suffer from poor level design and a lack of emotional connection or progression. Rogue Legacy, however, manages to subvert the latter in a very intriguing way, even if I feel that many of the more negative trappings of Roguelike games haunt this title.The game continues to suffer from the poor level design of its contemporaries. Being a Metroidvania inspired title, with a massive vania and a small sobbing Metroid being dragged along with it, this isn't as big of an issue as it could be. But in a genre which so clearly has great level design laid out for it, it would've easily been possible to make this game have fantastic level design, due to the way it randomizes levels. At current, it has large amounts of enemy spam and doesn't really let you take advantage of your characters' particular abilities very well, aside from the base core mechanics.Unlike other Metroidvania titles, this game doesn't introduce new weapons or game mechanics as you progress through the game, but linear upgrades like higher HP stats, strength, and different classes whom usually have a unique ability not directly related to combat or movement, and shuffled stats. The game's character progression is relatively weak, is what I'm saying.But despite suffering from weak character progression and poor level design, this game has a certain permanence to your actions which other roguelikes don't. Your upgrades and unlocks stay with you as you play. Even with what is ostensibly the game's prestige mode, old upgrades and traits are kept and even enhanced. It culminates in a very enjoyable experience where you never necessarily feel like you've 'lost' much outside of the dungeons resetting, and you can pick up the game and continue right from where you left off again.In terms of game design, this is a rather poor title, but it participates in filling the niche of a more replayable game following the core concepts of Metroidvania style action platforming. A niche which was previously very empty.If the idea of a Metroidvania game which focuses on replayability sounds good to you, even if it has fairly poor level design and a progression system that leaves me lukewarm to it, it's very much so worth a try.I look forward to seeing the future offerings of Cellar Door Games. It's rumored that they're planning to start work on a Rogue Legacy sequel in the future, to which I would say that it should basically be this, with a more varied progression system featuring more substantial changes to movement mechanics and weapons, along with more stark level design, potentially killing the 'castle' segments altogether.But as it stands, this game fills both a unique niche, and one with very wide appeal. It is worth playing in many senses of the word, but with clear flaws and a lack of polish regarding many of the core ideas.

												Rogue Legacy is one of those games that perfectly balances the simple with the hectic. The game could be called simple, like many side-scrollers can, but there's a lot worth thinking about and strategic decisions to be made in regard to the upgrade tree for your character. While the various rooms of the castle explored by your hero can be quite chaotic, it's never completely overwhelming. The difficulty level in this game is perfectly balanced for it's play-style (dying a lot but not too much or in a bad way.) The game has great replay-ability as when you "beat" the game, the difficulty is notched up and you simply continue on, with the same character even.The game does a fantastic job with it's subtleties and humor without losing sight of the actual gameplay. The two are spliced together almost perfectly. It's supported by solid achievements and trading cards. Rogue Legacy is completely enjoyable. It'd be hard to regret purchasing it. I know I never will.Strongly suggest giving it a try! It really is a great experience.

												Rogue Legacy is easily one of the most addicting games I have played in a while.At first, it is frustratingly difficult - but that is okay, as with every one of your pitiful deaths, the gold you collect through your adventure can be used to buy upgrades for your future heirs - be it unlocking new classes, or increasing health. Each of your heirs is flawed in some way - be it the curse of I.B.S., dementia, or savantism, every adventure will be different with your new hero through a dynamically generated castle, forest, and other spooky areas.This game is best played on an Xbox 360 controller -I have both wired PS2 and Xbox 360 controllers, and the 360 one works best for me.The nice part about this game is you can play pickup games whenever you want to blow a little steam off without getting too heavily invested in the game. 5 minutes early for a meeting? Play a little Rogue, and be on your way.

er 29, 2013
												While the rogue-like (permadeath) system coupled with the randomizing castle can make you feel like you aren't making any progress initially, the game surprises with the gradual gains of building out your manor to unlock new classes and bonuses.The inclusion of traits adds more depth to the experience, even when the traits do nothing from a gameplay standpoint (e.g. baldness or being gay). It's kind of fulfilling in its own right to power through the castle with a lesbian dwarf ninja.The game has a good sense of humor, and there are nodding references here and there to other media (e.g. Skyrim, Naruto), and there is enough of a rhythm once you've upgraded things a bit to offset the frustration of starting from scratch every time you die (and you will die many, many times). Note that you do have the option to "freeze" the castle layout at a -40% gold intake penalty once you unlock the Architect.The concept is great, and the execution is clever and full of charm. I hope to see more games from this team.Notes:-Spellsword+Vampirism is a mighty combination.-The game can frustrate you by offering puzzles that are only possible if you re-equip and lock the castle layout.-Some traits that sound negative can be surprisingly useful (e.g. P.A.D., Dwarfism, O.C.D.).-It's nice to play as a gay hero (without any stereotypical humor), especially after reading the developer's comments on why they included it.

												At first, I only bought this game because i liked the art style, but now, after beating the main story, I absolutely love this game.To start, the whole concept of "no two castles are the same" is done very well, with defferent rooms challenging different classes, plus there being secrets for characters with specific traits. The enimies are varied and intersting, esepcially the mini-bosses, even though at the beginning, you won't last very long. If you continue playing though, your skills will increase, as well as your armour, runes and stats. The 4 main bosses of each area are fun and are diffuclt, being extremley hard to beat them on your first time ( except the 4th boss, he is too weak to be the 4th area boss.) The controls are very good, with all the key assingments feeling natural. The finally thing is that the music in Rogue Legacy is some of the finest indie music I've heard. Overall, If you are a fan of Metroid, or the Metroid-Vanias, or are looking for a great indie game, this is the game for you. Also, on a side note, my longest living character was a midget, bald, assaisan.

												An absolutely amazing game. Rogue Legacy delivers on all levels. The music brings back memories of Diablo II. The look of the game is definitely classic Super Nintendo Ghouls and Ghosts, however the gameplay has merit in its own right. It does not really play like Ghosts and Goblins or its successor Ghouls and Ghosts, which is not a bad thing. Many different character classes can be unlocked and each class has its own special ability that takes mana. You will find new pieces of armor and runes as you play, which you can purchase after your character's inevitable permanent death. Upon death you will then choose an heir to keep your legacy alive. Each character has its own special traits that can help or hinder you along the way. The runes that you acquire will give your character new abilities or they can do things such as make enemies harder, but also give you more gold.Rogue Legacy is challenging, it will test your prowess. The game features a new game + mode, which makes it even more difficult and allows you to continue upgrading your manor and purchasing new armor and runes even after you have completed the game. The short storyline is good and it will keep you motivated to keep going.

												Great platformer for casual gamers. There is a game mechanic to prevent steady grinding away at it for gradual increase in resources, equipment, etc. where Charon requires you give up all (or, later on, a majority) of your currency to get back into the dungeon for each generation.This is the type of game where the player must primarily level up their real-life skills with the controller (or keyboard) for more success in the game, only mildly supplemented by in-game powerups that can be earned.While definitely geared toward a casual game here and there as time permits, the powerups are very diverse with a skill tree, collectible artifacts that unlock purchasable armor or abilities, and boss characters that are near impossible to beat without a very distinct strategy and some luck make this appealing for more hardcore retro-style players.One thing I would prefer is to have Steam Cloud enabled on here. I've already reinstalled my operating system twice since I started playing this and kicked myself for not making a backup of my save file.

ber 17, 2014
												At first, I only bought this game because i liked the art style, but now, after beating the main story, I absolutely love this game.To start, the whole concept of "no two castles are the same" is done very well, with defferent rooms challenging different classes, plus there being secrets for characters with specific traits. The enimies are varied and intersting, esepcially the mini-bosses, even though at the beginning, you won't last very long. If you continue playing though, your skills will increase, as well as your armour, runes and stats. The 4 main bosses of each area are fun and are diffuclt, being extremley hard to beat them on your first time ( except the 4th boss, he is too weak to be the 4th area boss.) The controls are very good, with all the key assingments feeling natural. The finally thing is that the music in Rogue Legacy is some of the finest indie music I've heard. Overall, If you are a fan of Metroid, or the Metroid-Vanias, or are looking for a great indie game, this is the game for you. Also, on a side note, my longest living character was a midget, bald, assaisan.

												I just keep coming back to this game.  Rogue Legacy is a game that can be enjoyed in small pieces but it takes a long time to master.  I love getting a little bit better every time I play.  The basic mechanic is that every time you die you start over as a new character, but any upgrades you've purchased persist. 2014
												This is a game that I didn't expect to get addicted to. Then again how would one know beforehand what one would be addicted to in a game?The genre of this one is RPG roguelike 2d platformer. I have seen so many reviews of people comparing this to the Binding of Issac. ♥♥♥♥ those reviews, this is nothing like that game. The only thing they have in common is that each run is different. In Rogue Legacy, you are basically running around in a castle collecting as much money as you can (for your legacy) and killing monsters (for yourself). Each time you enter the castle, it is different inside. Once dead, you must choose a new heir (1 of 3) to explore the castle. Everyone is different. Everyone has a unique name, a class, a gender, and random attributes that make them unique. The money you earn goes to that heir and is used for purchases of items/upgrades/unlocks and must be used before going into the castle. What you choose to purchase stays for every character (equipable items can be switched/unequipped). Everyone gets 1 life to live. There are some small exceptions to things I've mentioned, but that's via unlocks anyway.

When you die (WHEN you die), you upgrade various slots on your Mansion with the gold you earned going through Castle Hamson to better various skills and attain new abilities. Get it now.

												First of all whoever coined the term "Roguelike" should be shot.That aside, Rogue Legacy is a short 2d (I refuse to say roguelike) platformer with some twists. As probably ever other review tells you, your hero changes to your next heir when you die and the heir has the potential to be born with some positive or negative traits. You level by dying which is a strange system in itself. The castle randomly changes with every heir unless you choose to pay a fee to save your previous layout with the "Architect." Each heir retains stat and armor upgrades your previous heirs had. As your characters get stronger, so do the mobs.Pros: - Harder than most platformers. The difficulty level was perfect for me, not rage inducing, but hard enough to be of a challenge.- Castle layout changes and different challenges spawning kept the maps interesting.- Well planned bosses, except the last boss was kind of easy...- AddictiveCons:- If you're used to old school platformer controls, this feels nothing like them. Slow attacking forces you to play very differently.- Mage classes don't really feel like mage classes.- Can't hold the d-pad down + attack like in Adventures of Link. Downward attack doesn't hold. Lasts for only a split second.- Game balance could use some work as sometimes the scaling just felt off.

												Rogue Legacy is a roguelike platformer where you play as the offspring of your previous character, with varying abilities and quirks in the hopes of conquering the castle and claiming your birthrite. I completed Rogue Legacy, while doing a YouTube playthrough on YOGSCAST Nilesy, in around 22 hours. The game is incredibly fun and self-aware, leading to a super fun and enjoyable experience.My favourite part of the game were the character quirks: one character may be an Endomorph, so maybe they can't be knocked back, or an Exomorph who is very likely to be knocked back, another can only see in black and white, another is a Dwarf and thus a shortened version of the others, and many, many others. The character quirks lead to immediately engaging gameplay, as every time you start the castle you are forced to play dependant on the character you have. The seamless interaction between character quirks and skill level is perfect and balanced, leading me to consider this to be one of the best current roguelikes on the market.The humour in the game is also fantastic and witty. The story is a little obvious and a little contrived, but the game is fully aware of the fact, and feeds off of it to deliver a poignant and satisfying conclusion.I should add that JUST after my 22 hour completion, the developers added a major content patch which added a hell of a lot of new content, so if you're a new player there will be tonnes for you to do.Highly recommended.Nilesy

3, 2014
												Let me start this off by saying I'm not a huge fan of 2D games with elements similar to this (Castlevania, etc..) but Rogue Legacy is a very refreshing take on the genre. The goal of the game is to fight your way through several areas including a castle, a forest, a tower, and a dungeon; all of which feel connected yet set apart from each other.There is one twist on the game however. Every time you die you will lose your character forever. FOREVER. While that may seem a bit dramatic and perma-deathy fear not! You will retain everything you previously earned with your character and pass it on to an heir who will inherit your treasures and continue your quest! With the gold you have earned you will be able to buy new armor, buy runes to enchant your armor, and upgrade the very extensive skill tree represented by your own castle! As you upgrade the skills tree it will branch off into different sections allowing you to unlock more classes to play as and more passive bonuses to your character.Now onto the characters.. you can play as several character classes off the bat and have the ability to unlock many more by upgrading your skill tree. Every character you play as will be different from the last, not only set apart by their different class abilities and stats, but also by randomized traits and magic abilities! Have you ever wanted your protagonist to be a gay, color blind barbarian? Well that is one of hundreds (possibly thousands) of different character combinations you can have! These traits can have either positive, negative, or neutral effects on your gameplay. You could gain the ability to knock enemies back further, or you could take more damage from enemies, or you might have irritable bowels and flatulate while jumping! Now finally in conclusion I feel like a pros and cons list would suit this game well, here you go!Pros:+ Randomized dungeons make dungeons fresh every time you play!+ The boss fights in this game are brilliantly designed and a blast to play, including the buffed up, more difficult versions of the fights.+ The extensive skill tree will satisfy that need to upgrade.+ Death doesn't feel as devestating as other games.+ Different character classes and traits keep the game interesting.+ Excellent comedy factors Cons:- While your first playthrough may take a long while because you need to learn how to play, the game is very small.- For casual players the game could get boring very quickly.- Classes don't feel too much different from each other- Not much depth in combat (Could be a pro or con)? F*CKING CARNIVAL GAMESAll in all I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun, 2D dungeon crawler/lootpalooza game to keep them occupied for a while. 85/100

Well when you play this game you will change your mind, this game is filled with challanges, powerful mobs, heroes with annoting, hard and sometimes useful traits but most of all a lot of fun.This game has been designed for people that know how to play hack and slash games and get get through the hard territories even with Vertigo, Stereo blindess and Colour Blindness.Through out the game you gotta earn money to expand your mannor, that's the only way you will survive further through the endless corridors of the castle in order to defeat the 1st out of 4 beasts, expanding your mannor will grant you things like more health, armour, attack and armour capacity, but also you'll be able to unlock new classes, upgrades to those classes, and other utilities, but importantly, unlock the Blacksmith, that will sell armour, Enchantress who will sell runes (NOTE: all those things you first gotta find in the castle) and an arichtect who for a a 30% of your money will lock the castle, why would it be useful? , 2014
 "I have lived a rogue's legacy..."	  SO MANY BABIES!	 So you're reading a review about Rogue Legacy? Odds are you either are coming to see if the hype around this game is warranted, or you've seen it was on sale and need that one last push to convince you that your purchase won't be in vain. While a bit lengthy, this review holds everything you could ever want to know before buying. WELL LET ME TELL YOU!!! This game is by far one of the most fun games I've purchased in a long while. I'll start with a synopsis of the game's plot, followed by the pros and cons of the game, and end it with an official rating and some inside info on gameplay.  Just scroll to the end and find my header titled "Gameplay" if all you want to know is "gameplay mechanics please, I don't need story info".	  Synopsis	  You are the heir to a throne occupied by a king who has fallen ill. To what, you don't entirely know. The king has set out on a quest to remedy himself by venturing in to a castle that has been rumored to be haunted for years on the outskirts of his land. Within this castle is the key to curing all sickness. If a hero proves himself worthy to battle through the arduous citadel, they will find themselves with the ultimate power to cure themselves of any ailment. Your father has disappeared. It was rumored he found himself the treasure within and decided to stay with his new found riches. Others believe he fell to the beasts that inhabit the dangerous depths. Regardless of his fate, this prompts your brother, the antagonist of the story, to begin his own journey into the castle and claim the fortune for himself. You play as a generation of heroes, all dedicated to saving the king, and rescuing your brother who also has appeared to be lost. Throughout your exploration of the castle, you stumble across various journal entries, chronicling your brothers advancements. I won't reveal the ending, but I will hint that the castle's riches are far more evil than any monster ever could be. As you begin your journey you find that the castle is most certainly under some type of spell... Every time a traveler enters the cold, unwelcoming halls, the rooms are randomized entirely. No floor plan is ever the same, causing confusion and plenty of surprises for any weary guest. Being a fortress for countless foes inhabiting the keep, your only reference is a map you create as you navigate each room. Moving from area to area, you find that the castle leads out to a haunted forest, a miasma of ghouls, and a crypt of darkness. Of course there is a mighty enemy that dominates each territory. These boss-like creatures are found out eventually to be previous explorers who have fallen victim to the castle's ultimate secret. The further your travels take you, the more accomplished you feel each time. But at what cost? At the end of each life, you reawaken as new kin. A son or daughter to the previous explorer's family. Countless years pass, and you find that entire generations of warriors are dedicated to a pointless cause it would feel. Will your efforts prove fruitless? Will the castle's secrets finally be unlocked? What of the long lost king, and your traitor of a brother? Spoilers:  Play the game. It takes less than 20 hours to beat it no matter how new you are to it. You don't need spoilers <3	  Pros	 - Every new life leads to a highly randomized generation of soldiers, ready to fight your fight. This means that you will be able to constantly explore new play styles, receive new perks, and have a great time laughing at some of the unfortunate traits you receive. - The replay value of this game is through the roof. It's never the same, meaning each playthrough yields a new experience. - New Game + mode is exceptional. Like most games, there are new items, harder enemies, and even the storyline changes in minor ways. - The traits each character inherits that causes them to be unique, on top of their abilities their class grants them, leads to a fantastic character selection that makes each run memorable.  Cons	 - Many have reviewed this game to say that it is too difficult. I will not disagree with the thought that it is difficult, however, I will counter the argument with this: Once you get the momentum rolling, and build your character up a bit, the difficulty is something you enjoy and crave. Building your characters up is far more enjoyable with a real challenge before you. The difficulty that crushes so many is only temporary, as most will not play past the first hour due to frustration. - One major drawback of the game is that the skill tree is too limited and feels pointless at times. Once you've unlocked everything, you spend the rest of the time building small things like health and defense. You no longer have any real goal to aim for, you're simply buffing up your character. This occurs approximately 14-15 hours in, usually just before you defeat the penultimate boss, or clear the third area. A shame as new game + offers so much, yet leaves the skill tree lacking.  Gameplay/Rating	  Controls/Movement	 The game's controls are a bit difficult. As simple as they are, you'll find yourself going out of your way to execute a much more difficult approach to combat, rather than the intended one. An example of this is the "downstrike" ability. You should have the ability to jump over an enemy, and attack below you. However, the attack is too fast, and you end up hurting yourself, by being susceptible to enemies. Instead, now you'll learn that it's best to jump around all over place, narrowly avoiding attacks, and attacking from the side, to avoid damage. Movement does feel very fluid despite its speed, and you are able to manipulate your character well. The additional perks of certain traits lends itself greatly to gameplay, as some characters have the ability to go where others cannot, some are not knocked back by hits, and some are able to send enemies flying.  Items/Skills/Stats	 Cellar Door Games outdid themselves with the items and skills in this game. The various weapons you can find, equipment you can earn, runes that will allow for special techniques or perks, and items that can assist you (or one in particular that horribly ruins you), are all brilliantly put together in this game. As said before, the only area where they fall short, is the stat system. Once you've unlocked everything in the skill tree, you are left to adding to stats while you yearn for more unlockables. The character system that has you choosing between being "The One" and going on a Tron-esque journey into the grid, or having insatiable bowels that cannot stop playing you the song of its people, helps really flesh out this game and give you a feel of infinite scenarios/builds.  Rating/Recommendation On a scale of 0-10 (keeping it simple), I'll give this game a fantastic 9/10. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has even gotten this far in the review. Trust me, it is extremely deserving of your time. Cellar Door Games has created a fantastic way to expend your time. A few honorable mentions are that this game does a great job of helping you truly appreciate the story... The tutorial portion of the game ends up being the last path you take before the end of the game. The dialogue is fantastic and makes you laugh from to time, and of the last statements by the last boss... "Truly I have lived a rogue's legacy"... it definitely struck me. This game is fantastic. I will find myself playing it again and again, restarting a character or continuing off of an accomplished one. Please enjoy this, and see what all the hype is about. Would I invest my time in writing so much if I didn't think this game was freaking amazing?! Thanks for reading. The fact that you did means you and I both are great at wasting time.

9, 2014
												TL;DR: Fun, challenging roguelike platformer that'll take you a solid 20-30 hours of playtime to fully complete.  Things I Wish I'd Known To anyone thinking of getting the game and just starting out, a few recommendations. First, a controller is almost mandatory for this game. There's no mouse support, and while you can use two hands on a keyboard, it feels pretty awkward (and this game involves a lot of twitch reflexes and precision jumping). Also, there's an option to just press down to perform down attacks in the air or fall off platforms (I forget the name, but it should be obvious in the options menu) that's very helpful. And finally, try not to spend an excessive amount of time on the grind - if it's getting repetitive, clear through the bosses and attempt the next game mode. The Steam achievements for this game are actually a good balance of "difficult but not impossible," and getting all of them should indicate that you're essentially "done" with the game. You'll likely get 20-30 hours out of this game before getting that feeling of " why did I just waste all my time on that? " but if you enjoy a challenge and find it at a good price, it's definitely worth a look. Regular Review-y Part Rogue Legacy is an excellent roguelike platformer with a clever continuity mechanic. Gold and items collected during dungeon attempts can be used to provide static stat bonuses for future attempts, allowing the player to shore up their weak spots and fueling the game's progression system. The different classes and powers (via glyphs) provide enough variety to keep subsequent dungeon runs varied and interesting.The game can be punishing at first, but this is intentional, as it allows the player to see the effects of their stat purchases and armor upgrades, as well as their improving play. Rogue Legacy is a game that encourages player mastery - better play will lead to greater completion of the dungeon and more gold to spend for the next round. And just when you've gotten good enough to clear the dungeon and defeat all the bosses, the game will ramp up the difficulty with a "New Game +" mode. The new mode allows you to keep all your progress, but is balanced well enough that the previously easy intro part of the dungeon is now challenging again. The game also includes five "hidden" bosses, which are far more challenging versions of the standard bosses. These can be taken on at any time (your purchased stat bonuses don't affect the stats of the avatar during these challenges), but they provide a sort of endgame for players who have found the rest of the dungeon too repetitive. That said, I'd recommend looking up the slightly gamey strategy for defeating Alexander IV, as the "normal" strategy will lead to an absurdly challenging and probably frustrating fight.The game isn't without its downsides. The grind can feel a little repetitive at times, and there could be more indication that defeating the bosses on the first run through isn't the end of the game (as it is, it's confusing that by the time you're able to tackle the bosses in the first playthrough you've barely bought into the stats, and you won't have found all the armors). Not helping the repetitiveness is the music. It's not bad, at first, but after a few hours you'll want to turn on something else with more variety. But in the end, those are two relatively minor downsides in an otherwise great game.

												An excellent Castlevania-style platformer with roguelike elements. Because gold and upgrades carry over between characters, permadeath doesn't make you feel like your run was wasted when you eventually miss a jump and fall onto a bed of spikes. Combat is fairly simple, but pleasantly fast-paced, and the assorted challenge rooms, random positive and negative perks, and various other nuances make repeated trips into the castle very entertaining. I do wish there was a bit more enemy variety (there's a fair number of palette swaps), and some of the rooms show up more often than I'd like, but overall Rogue Legacy is definitely worth a look for platformer fans and roguelike fans alike.

												10/10I can’t overstate how great this game is. This might be one of my favorite games of all time. It’s incredibly challenging yet deeply rewarding. You will find yourself dying over and over again yet you are happy to come back for more punishment. The idea of having to pick a character – each with their own strengths and weaknesses – from a randomized gene pool is a great concept. Sometimes you will simply have to concede defeat and sometimes you will luck out and prepare yourself for a long run into unknown worlds. The randomized castles are a great mechanic that provides a fresh experience every time you restart. The ability to unlock power ups and game-changing mechanics is unique and fresh and allows for much more gradual difficulty curve. Eventually you should be able to beat the game; the question is how many hours will it take? It took me just under 20 hours to beat the final boss. The game is hard but not Spelunky hard.

y 9, 2014
												I was bored. I was looking for something fun and light to take my mind away from all the more serious games I'd been playing. I found it.Well, truth be told, I wasn't actually expecting to enjoy Rogue Legacy all that much, I really only picked it up because a friend had recommended it, and fully expected to get bored quickly. That's basically the opposite of what happened.The graphics are cute, and who doesn't like to do the occasional dungeon-crawl with adorable graphics? I was hooked within minutes. At this point, I find myself playing it for a little while most days. I'll decide "just one more character, just one more dungeon-crawl and then I'll go to bed... A few hours and a whole bunch of deaths later, I usually do. This is probably one of the most addictive little games I've played in a long time. The idea behind it is really very simple. You play a child from each of a succession of generations of one family, you can choose which, out of three random options, and in you go. The dungeon is different each time, unless you pay the Architect to give you the same one again, and until you pay for the upgrade that lets you pay Charon a little less, the ferryman charges you all your gold to get in. That's a real pain, makes it harder to stockpile your gold. You need that gold to upgrade your stats. Eventually, you face the bosses in it, but you can choose when to go through those doors, and they stay defeated through each generation after they're beaten. The story itself is told through diary pages that you find randomly.But sometimes the simplest ideas are the best, and this game is a whole lot of fun.

												My legacy has gone rogue. My 7-year-old has been playing it and he likes the Knight class so much he doesn't want to upgrade it to the Paladin... which means that he cannot unlock any upgrades and his potentially awe-inspiring castle remains a small fort. Each to their own, I suppose.Anyway, I enjoyed this game - great for a quick blast, plenty to explore and I felt great about finding the hidden class (at the top of the flagpole). It seems very much designed for an XBox controller, though, so playing on mouse and keyboard was difficult (I had to work out and write down the mappings from XBox controls to keyboard controls, plus the down-attack move to activate platforms is far too difficult on the default settings).It would be nice to carry over money from previous generations to allow the more casual player to build up a fortune... as it was, I found it increasingly difficult to be able to spend my money on anything useful (but did find that investing in the 'vampire' items and runes helped my character survive for longer to get the money). Also, some guidance on the order to attempt the other levels would be useful too (unless I missed something in the notes). Still, I enjoyed the various classes and weird hero traits, and the game overall.

content:
er 29, 2013
												While the rogue-like (permadeath) system coupled with the randomizing castle can make you feel like you aren't making any progress initially, the game surprises with the gradual gains of building out your manor to unlock new classes and bonuses.The inclusion of traits adds more depth to the experience, even when the traits do nothing from a gameplay standpoint (e.g. baldness or being gay). It's kind of fulfilling in its own right to power through the castle with a lesbian dwarf ninja.The game has a good sense of humor, and there are nodding references here and there to other media (e.g. Skyrim, Naruto), and there is enough of a rhythm once you've upgraded things a bit to offset the frustration of starting from scratch every time you die (and you will die many, many times). Note that you do have the option to "freeze" the castle layout at a -40% gold intake penalty once you unlock the Architect.The concept is great, and the execution is clever and full of charm. I hope to see more games from this team.Notes:-Spellsword+Vampirism is a mighty combination.-The game can frustrate you by offering puzzles that are only possible if you re-equip and lock the castle layout.-Some traits that sound negative can be surprisingly useful (e.g. P.A.D., Dwarfism, O.C.D.).-It's nice to play as a gay hero (without any stereotypical humor), especially after reading the developer's comments on why they included it.

y 26, 2014
												When you think of roguelikes, you normally think of randomness, high difficulty, and most importantly, permadeath. Dying in those games is very serious, you lose everything: Characters, stats, items, all gone. In that genre, death really means Game Over. But what if it didn’t have to be that way? Enter Rogue Legacy.You are a warrior tasked with exploring a magical castle and defeating monsters within, with Castlevania-like gameplay that should be familiar to everyone. The twist is that, when you die, that character is gone, and you start playing as one of their heirs, with different traits and classes. The money and treasure gathered by the deceased are passed on, and you can spend them on upgrades and equipments for the new generations.The game manages to keep a constant sense of progress with the upgrade system; dying is not the end, it’s the beginning of a new adventure where you’re likely to be better prepared. It’s not just about getting better stats and armor, either, you’ll also unlock new classes and mechanical improvements, like dashes and air jumps.Your descendants are, however, randomly generated. This goes for both class and traits, the latter of which are characteristics like "Glaucoma" or "Dwarfism" that can be very helpful, irrelevant, or highly crippling. The unreliability inherent to the heirs often forces you to adapt to something that "will do" instead of having the best for the task available, which makes victory all the more sweet.And of course, it wouldn’t be a roguelike if the journey through the castle was always the same. It changes, but not simply for each game: It changes on every single generation. This is why you don’t want to die too early: You miss the chance to get a lot of loot, and boss rooms are transferred elsewhere. On the other hand, a new character means new treasure to find, so it’s not that bad. It’s fun, both to win, and to lose.And that is Rogue Legacy: A game that avoids being frustrating, but still without making you feel you’re getting off easy. All the balance in the gameplay elements really shows that a lot of effort was put into making this game, and it paid off, because Rogue Legacy makes for a fantastic roguelike*, and probably for one of the best Castlevanias out there, too.* “Roguelite”, if you prefer.PS: Use of a controller is highly recommended.

ry 19, 2014
												Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/rogue-legacy-game-review/Ahh, Rogue Legacy. My favorite rogue-like game, although it also served as my introduction to the genre. Even after playing a lot of others from the genre now, I still look back on Rogue Legacy as my favorite out of the bunch.The game is presented in a pixel fashion, making use of some nice looking sprites for the various people and enemies you will meet along your journey. This style fits well, especially for a game of this genre. Come to think of it, I don't think I've played a rogue-like that was not in this style, and I've played several of them over the past several months. Can't really complain either, there's nothing wrong with it and I'd actually prefer this style in a rogue-like game, although I may be a bit biased there (heh).Rogue Legacy's niche is the rebirth mechanic. Upon dying as one character, you'll have the choice as to which of the three offspring of that character you'll play as next. The interesting thing about this mechanic however, is that each child has separate traits, disguised as real world disorders and conditions. These can either be in your favor or against it. ADHD, for example, works in your favor in that your character will move 30% faster than usual. My favorite defect is vertigo, which mirrors the screen vertically. Yes, everything, including menus. Vertigo is a pain to deal with as I cannot rotate my monitor upside down, forcing me to play upside-down.Aside from that gimmick, the other half of the game is the immense class and upgrade system. You'll start off with no skills, playing as the default class, the knight. Upon death, the opportunity to choose offspring with a different class is presented. The basic classes to choose from contain classes such as: mage, knave, knight, barbarian, shinobi, miner, etc. Each class can be upgraded, getting a name change in the process. The shinobi, for example, changes into the hokage, my favorite class. Each class has its own advantages and disadvantages, keep that in mind.The shinobi/hokage has the benefit of upgraded strength (175% to be exact), but at the cost of only having 60% HP, 40% MP, and not being able to take advantage of critical hits. I never really used the game's spells, so the MP cut didn't have much of an effect on me, but the HP and critical hits were quite the drawback. Even so, whenever I was given the opportunity to play as a hokage, I always took it. You can't beat 175% damage. I found it crucial to defeating some of the game's bosses. I actually defeated the forest boss (the second one I took on) without getting hit as a hokage, quite the achievement.On top of the classes, there's also a plethora of upgrades to choose from each time you die. The upgrades are laid out in a branching format, with certain upgrades unlocking others. The first one made available is Smithy, the blacksmith. Once purchased, you'll be able to purchase both armor and weapons from him. There's also an architect (who can keep the last layout of the castle if you choose to not want the game to randomly generate another castle again) and an enchantress, who sells runes, which can be equipped to provide various abilities (like the ability to jump while in air).The other upgrades consist of class upgrades (like barbarian -> barbarian king) and stat upgrades. This consists of mana, health, and equip upgrades. Equip upgrades allow you to carry more weight and is required if you ever want to wear good armor. There's plenty of other upgrades to base skills (attack up, magic damage up, armor up, etc.) and a few unique ones, like "death defy" and "haggle". Death defy, as you can probably tell, allows you to defy death (1.5% everytime the upgrade is purchased). Haggle, on the other hand, lowers Charon's toll when entering the castle.The game's map is divided into five zones: the front "safe" area at the entrance to the castle, the castle, the maya (above the castle), the dungeon (below the castle), and the forest (to the right of the castle). Each area (aside from the safe area) has its own boss that needs to be defeated if you want to unlock the golden door at the entrance of the castle. These bosses are very difficult if you're not properly equipped (I did tell you about my love for the hokage class, right?). Each time you die and want to re-enter the castle, you'll have to give up all of your funds earned during the previous run to Charon, who guards the entrance to the castle.Rogue Legacy is a fantastic game overall. The sense of progression is really profound and it just feels really, really satisfying to defeat the bosses and open that golden door. Now that it's only $15, why not give it a shot?

er 22, 2014
9/10, Best roguelike I've ever playedI'm going to be honest right from the start; one of the main reasons I purchased this game is because of this right here.Originally posted by RogueLegacy Devs: Ever wanted to be dyslexic? Now you can! Seriously though, this game can be casual (General dungeon crawling, looting, etc) or hardcore (Each boss has a more powerful "remixed" form), and it is just fun to play. There is just so much for me to say about this game and I don't know where to start. The combat, the upgrades, the classes, the traits, the death (so much death), it all just comes together in a legendary game. Pros:+++ Replayabiltiy. This game has a lot of it. +++ Classes and traits that actually do stuff. Are you tired of upgrades and skills that just add % modifiers and generic bonuses? The trait system in this game actually affects gameplay in a meaningful way, whether its vertigo flipping the screen upside-down, or runes that let you fly. They also threw in generic bonuses. But ya' know.++ Satisfying kills. When you hit or kill an enemy, it'll just feel plain good. ++ Remix bosses. Its like playing dark souls, if the bosses in dark souls were optional, on a 2d platformer, and had weaker forms (The actual bosses). If you're not looking for a hardcore, half-impossible experience, you can just ignore them altogether and its still an awesome game.++ Procedurally generated. Randomness is the spice of life.+ Nice music. Always good to have.+ No penalty for death. If you're like me and have biophobia (the fear of life), then you'll be golden.Cons--- The controls. Default controls for keyboard are simply terrible. There's just no way to sugarcoat it. I spent the better part of my first hour playing constantly readjusting them. BUT. But there is an option of using a controller, and many people (I haven't used one) say that it is a lot better. Don't worry too much if you don't have a controller, a keyboard worked well for me.I'm not going to tell you that everybody should buy this game. If you don't like roguelikes or if you have a burning hatred of platformers, then this game isn't for you. It can be played casually or not, so it covers most people on that front. Its a hack 'n slash at heart, featuring dungeon crawling and lucrative chests. It has "fairy chests" which require you to complete a specific goal before they can be opened, and they contain a rune which can be applied to give your character special powers and buffs. I just realized I didn't even talk about one of the core mechanics, children. When you die, your current hero will be gone forever, but thankfully 3 of his children will be nominated to take his place. You can pick any one of them to wander off into the castle and risk their lives for treasure (Sorry, but it turns out momma did pick favorites!). These 3 children are of a random class, granted you've unlocked that class, and have 0-2 random traits. Each class differs in stats, and each has a unique "special" ability that can avoid damage, clear a room, etc. Traits will affect gameplay in various ways. Some are very helpful, others can be harmful, and some can be good in some situations, while terrible in others. I would keep rambling about how great this game is, but if you've made it this far in the review, then you're obviously interested in the game and should just buy it already. You know you want to.

												Rogue Legacy is a highly addicting procedurally-generated rogue-like that is definitely worth playing. You battle your way through a castle, unraveling it's mysteries, and upon your death, your child succeeds you in your quest. You have your pick from three children every time, each one unique in that it may have positive or negative mutations. You also get to continuously upgrade your armor/weapons/skills/stats after death with the gold collected in your previous run. The upgrading mixed with the simple but fun platforming makes Rogue Legacy a delightfully addicting game. It is a great choice for anyone who enjoys rogue-likes and definitely worth picking up.

												In a nutshell: Roguelike-lite Metroidvania with upgrades. I was hooked once I played the demo, and the full game is significantly more awesome and fleshed-out.
