content:
er 22, 2013
												I love this game so, so much. This is probably one of my Top 20 games, ever.I love Castlevania, I love procedurally generated games, and I love roguelikes. This game is a fantastic mashing-together of all three. I really don't feel that they could have integrated these three genres any better.The character progression and growth feels amazing. I suppose it's technically possible to beat the end boss on your first non-tutorial life, but it feels exactly as horrible and impossble a task as it should, with no powers, wealth, or weapons to help you out. As you get the hang of the game and learn its secrets, you unlock more and more powers to pass on to future generations, and eventually manage to barely scrape past bosses you've been pouring incredible amounts of time into. It's refreshing for a modern game to demand this much of you, and it's a lot of fun to take the challenge.Protip: If you buy this, it's playable and fun without a controller, but it's so much better with one. The controls really feel natural on a controller, which is something that I feel is pretty rare. The characters' movements feel tight, but also really fluid, which is something I've really only experienced previously with Super Meat Boy.At the time I'm recommending this, the game's on sale for less than $5. This game is worth so much more than that. It felt like a steal for $15. If there's ever any DLC for this, I'm impulse-buying it.Buy this game. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2013
												Rogue Legacy is a semi-Rogue-like Metroid/Castlevania-style 2D action/platformer, where you explore a changing mansion and try to clear the enemies and treasure out of it. Death is permanent, but when you die, your offspring take your place, and with the money you collected in your last run, you can buy items that will help with every future attempt.Rogue Legacy is a difficult game, and you will die many times as you play. The nice thing is that when you die, the castle layout changes, meaning that you won't keep dying to the same stupid trap. You do lose all of your money when you re-enter the castle, so you'll have to purchase upgrades with only the money you got on your last run, So, if you well on your run, you can buy a nice upgrade. If you do poorly, just enter the castle again and hope for a better layout. So, while this game is pretty difficult, it's not nearly as frustrating as a lot of other tough games are, even on those early runs where you die without getting anything at all.If course, the gimmick of this game is that each different hero has different traits that alter gameplay. It's funny, but doesn't significantly change things most of the time.I played with an XBox controller, and the controls worked pretty well for me. The music is solid. The graphics are pretty nice, though some of the filters that certain traits add get very annoying.If this sort of game looks interesting to you, definitely pick it up. I've had a lot of fun with Rogue Legacy. Inexperienced gamers may have a difficult time getting very far, though.

er 22, 2013
												Rogue Legacy is like an indie version of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.  The game is polished for what it is.  The intro starts as you're a knight that kills an evil king in a castle.  Flash forward to present where you play as the son of that knight that goes into this castle to find out what happened to your father.  Each time you die in the game you play as the son or daughter of the previous knight.  Each generation has different traits and character types that change how you play the game.  The castle layout changes each time you die and enter the castle.  Also, when you pick a new heir to go questing you get the inheritance money of the previous knight which you can use to purchase new swords, armors, or build your own castle to unlock power-ups and new knight types.  This game is loads of fun and has great replayability.  It's a steal at $5 and worth the regular price.

												The name already says what this game is about. Its an awesome rogue-like. You try to conquer a castle of your ancestors while you jump and kill in a beautiful 2D-world. 												This is one of those wonderfull games, you promise yourself you'll play for 10 minutes just before you have to go to work, and then realize you didn't just miss work, but also dinner, that one show you love and about 7 years of your life. Randomly generated maps and rooms, keep the gameplay fresh and exciting, with 4 different 'worlds' to explore and about as many variations of enemies you can imagine. The 'hero' choice is very refreshing, and each character has a randomly assigned class and features. For example colourblind, or gigantism. There really are a lot of those little touches and they change the gameplay tremendously even if you don't think they could. The bosses are challenging, but you can quickly find your favourite strategy to beat them. Thedifficulty might seam a bit unfair at the strt since you will die... a lot, but at the same time, it's easy enough to learn how to avid enemy attacks and navigate in the tight spaces filled with spikes from every side.All in all I recomend this game completely to anyeone and everyone.

												Great game. Platforming combined with roguelike features provided me with hours of fun. Each run allows you to improve your "character" in small ways. content:
, 2014
												A fun, procedural rogue-lite, rouge-like, whatever you what to call it.  The randomization of rooms and enemies is well-done, despite the different zones sharing a ton of similarities with the big difference being a coat of paint.  Rogue Legacy also controls really tight, even when you're triple-jumping or flying around the screen with about a dozen enemies crowding around you.  Since you're going to spend most of the game jumping and dodging, good controls are extremely important.The big push of the game, playing as your offspring with different traits, actually is a bit of a letdown.  All characters have the same basic controls and models and share most of the same skills.  Playing as a mage character will involve a lot of the same running, jumping, and sword-swinging as a knight, just with a few minor differences.  The character traits are mostly a mixed bag, with a decent bit of them being one-off things you try once (like vertigo) and never bother with it again.  Some are useful, but more often than not you're going to end up picking the heir with the least negative traits rather than any with a particularly cool effect.Enemies are heavily re-skinned in Rogue Legacy, you'll be fighting same 8-12 enemies most of the game.  This doesn't really bother me since the gampelay is smooth and controls so well and combat is more of a mortal affair where enemies and the player character can both die rather quickly.  Then there's the bosses, easily the worst part of the game for me.  They're not even original enemies, just the same ones you fight over and over but much bigger.  That's the not bad part though.  The actual boss fights are mostly bullet hell sequences when you have to avoid twenty other things going on, dodging the huge boss, and trying to fight all the while.  It's quite annoying to fall onto one of a half-dozen floating spike balls or twenty lingering flames and die while jumping frantically to avoid a boss.  All five bosses in the game have this type of gimmick and they're more frustrating than entertaining.Rogue Legacy is also a bit on the bland side visually.  The character art and backgrounds are perfunctory and that's it.  Music is catchy but not particularly memorable.While it seems I spent most of the review nit-picking about the game, I greatly enjoyed most of my playthough.  The most important aspect of this sort the game, the gameplay, is really good.  The progression system is pretty rewarding and just exploring the castle is fun.  I'd definitely recommend it to anyone that enjoys 2-D platformers or fans of the traditional Castlevanias.

content:
25, 2016
												I ran forward through the castle complex, but no matter how hard I squinted, the world outside the small bubble of clarity around me remained blurry and out of focus. “Damn this short-sightedness,” I muttered before hacking at a beast in my path. Nothing. The damn blade passed right through it. Oh great, I’m seeing things again. Dementia’s a ♥♥♥♥♥.Welcome to Rogue Legacy, a game quite unlike anything else I’ve come across. Looking for all the world like a 2D action-platformer, behind the charming pixel art presentation is a consistently surprising experience, packing a dizzying array of variables.It’s all anchored by robust Roguelike game design, which means a procedurally generated world and perma-death. Each time you enter the castle, its layout and the challenge ahead will be different, and if you die, well, that’s the end of that hero - it’s time to send one of his heirs in to try and finish the job. Thankfully, the meta-game lets you spend any gold earned during the last run on your family’s fort, which means unlocking new classes and perks, and upping your stats for the next attempt.CaptionThe core sword and spell action-platforming is tightly designed.And boy, there’s going to be a lot of attempts. When you first start playing Rogue Legacy you might last a minute or two before succumbing to one of the ghouls, undead, or other nasties that lurk inside the castle complex. It’s a classic 30-second gameplay loop – hacking, slashing, running, jumping, dashing, evading, and spellcasting, repeated until you die. This core gameplay is compelling in and of itself - Rogue Legacy is wonderful to control provided you have a good gamepad - but to make true progress you’ll need to boost your stats, get better equipment and activate perks. Gradually your runs will get longer and longer. Then you’ll wander into a higher-level area and die almost instantly.The cycle of life, eh?It’s an excellent way to structure the challenge, and really puts the fear of god into you. You may be kicking ♥♥♥ in what amounts to Rogue Legacy’s foyer, but boy, you’re not ready for the forest yet, or – god forbid – the dank dungeons underneath the castle. This is a game where your best option is to turn and run away if you enter an area you’re not ready for. This is a game where it may be several hours before you beat the first boss – despite being able to reach it in a matter of minutes - and many more before you’re ready for the next. Good thing the bosses stay dead after you die, otherwise beating Rogue Legacy would be an even more distant prospect.CaptionThe bosses can be next to impossible with the wrong character, but as you'd expect, learning their attack patterns is key.Now, levelling up is all well and good, but Rogue Legacy has one very unique trick up its sleeve in addition to this. I’ve already mentioned that you send an heir in to continue the fight after each death, but you actually get a choice of three, and each has a random class, random spell, and random traits. Traits? Yup, and they’re glorious, surprising and bewildering. Ever played as a hero suffering from vertigo and OCD? How about a colour blind protagonist who also has Alzheimer’s? ADHD and dementia anyone? Tunnel vision and irritable bowel syndrome? The list goes on and on.The really clever part of this system is that many of these traits have significant gameplay ramifications: ADHD means you move faster, far-sightedness and near-sightedness leave areas of the screen blurry, and characters with dementia will hear things and see enemies that aren’t there. Dwarves, meanwhile, are so light and small they don’t activate spiked floor panels and can access areas no other characters can.Of course, some traits really have been included just for fun. Dyslexia, for instance, means any in-game text is garbled, while a character with coprolalia (Tourette’s syndrome) will swear any time he or she gets hit. Heroes with hypochondria, on the other hand, will have much larger numbers pop up any time they take damage, while you’ll probably avoid vertigo at all costs – unless you’re a masochist – because who wants their world to be upside down? Getting your head around the traits system is all about working out what comes with meaningful changes to the world and how that factors into your play style.The world near long-sighted heroes is out of focus.Cool, right? And that’s really just a taste – there’s plenty more for you to discover when you play it yourself... which you absolutely should. The traits are just one facet, too. Once you factor in the ten classes and all the spells characters can have, the list of potential combinations is incredibly long.It really is pot luck, and no matter how far through the meta-game you are, you will never know exactly what to expect. Of course, the further in you are, the more you’ve honed your skills and come to know how best to use each class, trait, and spell, and – crucially – how to select the random character that you can best utilise.The learning curve is right on the money, and almost every run has something to teach you, whether it’s an epic boss-killing mission with a heaven-sent character that’s able to survive a wide-roaming journey through the castle, or an abject, miserable failure with the best of a bad bunch. Mind you, the random nature of Rogue Legacy won’t be to everyone’s tastes - getting a series of dud characters can definitely feel punitive at times, as opposed to a learning experience.CaptionEvery class differs in core stats and special ability, while equipment and enchantments are class agnostic.Thankfully, the mix of enemies is quite compelling. Each area introduces new enemies - ninjas in Hannya masks, headless horses that charge the player - as well as fresh variants on old designs. Juggling a set of monsters with their own disparate attack patterns is a big part of the challenge. The five bosses represent a good mix of bullet hell and precision platforming too, whether you’re facing a huge flaming skull or a gigantic gelatinous blob.The castle holds more surprises than just rooms full of enemies. Special rooms abound, including carnival games, shrines, mini-boss battles, and plenty more. Perhaps the most interesting, however, are the fairy chest rooms. Each has a very specific challenge for you to beat. Kill everything! Get to the chest without jumping! Don’t fight! Don’t take damage! You get the idea.Unlocking a fairy chest will net you a rune that can be equipped for specific perks, like air-jumping, dashes, limited flight, extra gold, reflecting damage taken back onto enemies, gaining health/mana from kills, and so on. Best of all, these runes stack. So if you want to, you can spec your character with highly customised ability sets. Multiple air-jumps? Don’t mind if I do!While some of the fairy chest rooms can be conquered by almost any character, others require particular traits or sets of runes. Thankfully, you can use the Architect - one of three characters unlocked via your fort (alongside the Smithy and Enchantress) - to lock down the layout of the castle for successive attempts. He’s a great inclusion, and indicative of Rogue Legacy’s ability to balance random elements with tight, fair game design.In fact, if that balance was wrong, this game wouldn’t be anywhere near as compelling. It’s a testament to Cellar Door Games that the team was able to juggle so many elements and make it work.It’s one hell of a meaty undertaking too. The most adept players will be able to beat it in about 15 hours, whereas I sunk in considerably more time than that. It’s a lot of gaming for only $15 (USD $17 on PlayStation), and once you’ve finished your first play-through, New Game + awaits, which lets you keep all your stats, weapons and runes, but gives you a much harder variant of the castle to beat.9/10

THE ONLY THING I think it could be better was the music. It's cool, but I think that if had something like castlevania symphony of the night this game would be perfect. 												So, if you love things like Super Mario Bros. and Ghosts & Goblins and all that. And, if you love other things like Binding of Isaac and FTL and all that. Well, you are going to run around this castle pooping with glee.You've probably read that you can play as a gay dwarf or a stereo-blind assassin or whatever. And that's cool.Basically, there's some kind of mystery going on and your lineage keeps dashing into this big ole creepy castle because ... ADVENTURE. FAMILY. HUBRIS. Maybe the generation you're playing as will be the best castle explorer/fighter ever. Probably you'll die.But along the way you'll earn some gold. Through the magics of big ole creepy castles, all your gold will -- I dunno -- teleport or something back to your family manor. (NOT A SPOILER ALERT: I have no idea how this works. I have a feeling it is part of the mystery and maybe there's a big twist at the end where you find out something like ... the current manor is the past castle.) However it works, your color-blind son or gigantic daughter gets to buy some sweet new genetic traits with all that gold, and while you're doing that your manor gets bigger.Dash to castle. Die. Repeat.Oh. Also these three weirdos build a camp in between the manor and the castle. And they have armor and weapons and enchantments OR can freeze the castle the way you last saw it. FOR A PRICE.So, do that or don't do that. Then dash back into the castle. Kill flying wizard ghosts. Stab some giant skulls. Head out to the garden. To the haunted attic. Or to the scary basement. (You're more likely to die in each of those respectively.)As your family gets cooler and fiercer and dark artsier, you can venture a little longer and get more golds and build a cooler, fiercer, dark artsier gene pool.It's fun.If you're not a huge 2D platformer fan, you'll enjoy it but you probably won't be all like BINDINGOFISAACISTHEBESTGAMEEVER all over it, unlike Binding of Isaac or FTL or Risk of Rain.BUT. If 2D platformers are amongst your things. Be sure to bring a rag to clean up after yourself. Because that castle might be your manor. (HONESTLY. I HAVE NO IDEA.)

content:
er 25, 2013
												From interview with BigSushi.fm (http://bigsushi.fm/episode-79-cellar-door-games/)There’s something charming about talking to two developers who don’t know that they made a good game. When they released the trailer for the game, they were surprised it got so much attention. When they released a demo of the game to press, they weren’t confident about the praises being heaped upon them."It’s been a little overwhelming. We weren’t expecting this sort of response. I’ve been working under a rock for the last year and a half. At this point I’m sick of the game and I was certain it was garbage."It’s a sentiment shared by a lot of developers we talk with that haven’t reached critical appeal. When the brothers recollect the number of games they’ve worked on together they remember a lot of Flash games that were fun to make, but not commercially viable. But their not strangers to game development: Kenny worked for Capcom Mobile and Teddy was Lead Designer on Guacamelee! However, they consider Rogue Legacy their first big commercial release as Cellar Door Games.Rogue Legacy is described as a rogue-”lite” and is certainly not as punishing as a lot of rogue-like games. While dying in a lot of games is trying for many players, the legacy mechanic in their game makes each life unique and funny. The child you choose to avenge your death may have tourettes, irritable bowels, or have some form of gigantism creating a lot of interesting flair for your next play through."We like to take genres and twist them."The legacy mechanic along with unlocking upgrades to your castle, a massive skill tree, equipment and magic makes the game much more forgiving than other rogue-likes. You’re going to die, your children will have some problems, but you won’t be able to put the controller down.The brothers recognized the rogue-like mechanics in one of their favorite games, Demon’s Souls. It became an inspiration for their game as they described wanting to make something similar: a 2D Cartoony Demon’s Souls. When they started looking for artists, Glauber Kotaki had the exact style they wanted. The soundtrack from Gordon McGladdery and Judson Cowan (Tettix) is also fantastic. Although, we’ll still play a few sessions with the jazz music they originally were considering.Kenny and Teddy were a lot of fun to talk with about their history making games together, design docs, memes, Denny’s, and another entry in our unofficial poll on poutine.

content:
15, 2014
												Rogue Legacy is a platformer roguelike combined with RPG elements. During each run of the castle, it is possible to find new equipment and bonuses that are permanent. The next run through the castle you normally can buy a new stat or skill or some piece of equipment. The best way to find rare blueprints for the good equipment is by using a shrine in hopes to get a compass that will lead to a otherwise invisible room with 1 or 2 blueprints. However, this shrine also gives out CURSE OF THE HEDGEHOG. This curse causes you to lose hundreds of gold every time you take damage. If the gold doesn't land on spikes or impossible to reach places, it can be picked up again. When you receive this curse, the best thing to do unfortunately is to suicide on a monster while trying to pick up as much of your gold as possible. If this occurs in a low level area, it is even more annoying if your character has a lot of hit points left and a good armor rating.There is no mod to get rid of this "feature" and the game doesn't have steam workshop. The only way to advance your character is with gold, after you die. If you try to continue playing through a run with the curse on, it will not be a good use of your time or fun picking up tons of gold every single time any damage is taken.If the game was patched so that when instead of getting CURSE OF THE HEDGEHOG your character just lost 10% of his gold and instantly died while a big middle finger was displayed on the screen it would be an improvement.When running the game on OSX operating system, exiting the game will not shut it down. It has to be force quitted, or will continue running in the background and steam will record it as time played. The OSX version also suffers from periodic freezes or stutters. These usually aren't too bad, but it can mess up a boss fight or tricky jump.Other than that the game is fun and has a good soundtrack. It is fun to finish a run and go back into the castle with a new character and try out a new combination of gear. Hopefully the bad things are patched out at some point.

content:
5, 2014
												The whole retro-gaming thing is getting out of hand. I picked this up because it was only $5 on sale, and it looked like a nice casual break from other games. I immediately felt cheated. I have never wanted a refund so badly before. The feature of your descendants carrying on after you die sounded very cool, but the implementation is simply this: every time you start, you get to choose from only three characters with random traits and classes. The characters don't really have anything that ties them to the previous generation. Let's talk about the retro aspect of the game. What this means is it is very hard and repetitive. If I was playing with a controller, I would be constantly throwing it across the room. Progress is extremely slow and unrewarding. The worst part is, you cannot persistantly chip away at the game. Any progress can only be gained by massively successful rounds. This is because every time you upgrade your character, the cost increases. Combine this with the fact that every time you re-enter the castle, you forfeit all your gold. The impact of this game design choice is that you make ZERO progress over and over and over again, unless you have an amazing round. Then you are rewarded by increase perhaps one stat by 1 out of 100, or something like that. I cannot stress how much I hate this game.

content:
er 27, 2015
												Really good rogue metroidvania with a cool rune system where you can choose to either balance out a character's skill or max out one skill.+It'll have you sinking in hundreds of hours if you want to fiil up the skill tree, but you my choose to finish it quicker if you don't;+The art style is fitting and consistant;+Interesting legacy system, where you choose one of 3 heirs after each death based on your playstyle;+Turning medical conditions into power-ups and obstacles depending on playstyle;+Controlls are super responsive, so the difficult dodging parts are fair;+Organic difficulty, you can either win with lots of skill or spend hours levelling+Having high level doesn't turn the first pats of the map into a borefest since the enemies scale with your level;-O MAI FA KING GOD ADD STEAM CLOUD. I JUST LOST 200 HRS(don't look at my playtime, I had this gam through *other means* before I bought it) OF LEVELING BECAUSE OF YOUR BULL SHEET LOCAL SAVE FILE JESUS FA KING CHRIST.-The music is okay but it gets old quick so better get an audiobook or sth if you intend on 100%
